author: cbc
title: Alleged choking gesture against prosecutor means extra charges for Labrador woman
text:
A woman who appeared in provincial court in Happy Valley-Goose Bay this week for a bail hearing left the court facing more charges, after she allegedly made a choking gesture directed at a prosecutor.
Barbara Ann Mercer, 46, was charged with unlawfully intimidating, impeding a justice system participant and uttering threats to cause bodily harm.
The incident happened Wednesday, after she was denied bail on charges of drug trafficking and possession.
Sources within the justice system tell CBC that Mercer allegedly used her hands to make a choking gesture as she was being taken to cells by a court sheriff.
She also allegedly said she knows the location of family members of the prosecutor, and that if he is looking for trouble then he is going to find it.
She allegedly added she knows the Drukens, the St. John's family that has had a long history with the criminal justice system.
The incident happened after Mercer was denied bail for drug trafficking and possession charges at Happy Valley-Goose Bay court. (Bailey White/CBC)
The prosecutor involved did not want to speak to what happened but told CBC News that the fact that she knew where his family lived was concerning.
Mercer, who remains in custody, is scheduled to return to court on March 8.
